Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Triplet Polymer based Solar Cells as a New Path for Higher Efficiency

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Novel Triplet Polymer based Solar Cells as a New Path for Higher Efficiency


Abstract

The research goal of this career development plan is to generate a new type of highly efficient organic solar cells by creating a family of novel triplet conjugate polymers, with controllable energy levels and bandgaps ranging from infrared to visible regions that are currently unavailable. The current organic photovoltaics (PV) are primarily based on singlet polymers with short-lifetime excited states and narrow absorption spectrum, and suffer low efficiencies (6 ? 7 %). Thus, new materials are strongly needed to significantly increase the efficiency. Using long-lifetime triplet materials to increase the device efficiency is a much less explored area. The PI will address the fundamental issues in these unique triplet polymers and their applications in high performance organic solar cells. The specific research activities will include calculation and synthesis of new triplet polymers, fundamental understanding of the energy transport and generation processes in the new triplet polymers, and development of highly efficient triplet PV cells. The proposed work will potentially reveal some of the bottlenecks which have hampered high-efficiency polymer solar cell development, by providing a completely different avenue to the losses and limitations in the current singlet based polymers and devices.

The education goal of this career development plan is to advance discovery while promoting teaching and learning at all educational levels. The PI is committed to integrate this career development plan research with an educational outreach program and involve the participation of K-12, undergraduate and graduate students, including the Native American and female groups. An education-based polymer photovoltaic lab station will be developed for the South Dakota Mobile Science Lab. The Mobile Science Lab travels to schools around the state during the school year. The primary purpose of the Mobile Science Labs is to provide South Dakota students with an opportunity to perform science lab activities with advanced equipment, technology, and methods that are usually not available in small schools. Underrepresented undergraduate and graduate Native American and female students will be encouraged and directly hired to work in the PI?s laboratory.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes - intellectual merit

The research goal was to generate new organic solar cells using polymers with different bandgaps and triplet states, fundamentally understand the polymers, study the morphology using different donor-acceptor ratios, and fabricate high efficiency polymer solar cells, as well as build collaborations to develop the PI’s career. This work has generated significant number of publications and presentations. The key outcomes of this project include

  • Demonstrated the potential of triplet metallated materials for efficient solar cells
  • Demonstrated CsF as the electron-interfacial layer can significantly improve the PCE of the P3HT:PCBM polymer  solar cell with normal device structure
  • Found that solar cells which contained single layer metal oxide thin films as charge selective layers degraded faster than cells containing bi-layered films
  • Demonstrated that low molecular weight semiconducting polymers can be used for photovoltaic applications
  • Studied the combinations of metal oxide electron transport layers on the performance and stability of PSBTBT based inverted structured organic solar cells
  • Observed that PEIE interfacial dipole can provide ordered structure in the interconnecting layers (ICLs) for more efficient charge recombination processes and thus due to inclusion of PEIE in the device structure, FF improves from 55.6 to 59.3
  • Found that PEDOT/AZO/PEIE combination was the optimal interconnecting layers for tandem and multijunction polymer solar cells
  • Demonstrated that UV–ozone treatment on electron transport layer of PBDTTT-C-T/PC70BM polymer solar cells can improve cell performances.

 Outcomes - broader impacts

Overall the last 6 years, about 6 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral research associates have been trained in solar cell fabrication, characterization and testing. In addition, we have also provided lab tours to EE 102 freshman students in order for them to expose to the nanoscale fabrication and characterization facilities in the Nanocharacterization Lab and Organic Electronics Lab. Lab characterization facilities were also used for labs in the cross-listed undergraduate and graduate course EE4/560 Sensors and Measurements. We presented some of our research results to high school students that came to the summer camp in our department in summer 2015.
